titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ambassador Auditorium Collection ARS.0043
titlestmt.author: Frank Ferko and Anna Hunt Graves
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection has been processed under the auspices of the Council on Library and Information Resources with generous financial support from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-07-12 14:26:01 -0700.

physdesc.extent: Containers of various sizes with multiple types of print materials, photographic materials, audio and video materials, realia, posters and original art work (682.05 linear ft.).

did.abstract:
The Ambassador Auditorium Collection contains the files of the various organizational departments of the Ambassador Auditorium as well as audio and video recordings. The materials cover the entire time period of April 1974 through May 1995 when the Ambassador Auditorium was fully operational as an internationally recognized concert venue.
The materials in this collection cover all aspects of concert production and presentation, including documentation of the concert artists and repertoire as well as many business documents, advertising, promotion and marketing files, correspondence, inter-office memos and negotiations with booking agents. The materials are widely varied and include concert program booklets, audio and video recordings, concert season planning materials, artist publicity materials, individual event files, posters, photographs, scrapbooks and original artwork used for publicity. Many of the print materials include handwritten comments from office personnel and administrators, and many of the artist photographs are autographed.
Since the various office personnel maintained their own files, and the same information was often needed in more than one office at a time, the collection contains duplicate copies of many items. Although efforts were made to eliminate duplicate material from the same file or the same series, duplicate copies of items exist among the files from different offices. In an effort to maintain the original content of these files, the cross-file duplicate items were retained in the collection.

Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound,

Stanford, California 94305-3076
did.langmaterial: English, French, German, Italian, Korean, Spanish, Russian, Hungarian, Dutch, Latin, Malay, Thai, Czech, Slovak

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in ten series according to the original order established by the Ambassador Auditorium personnel: (1) Administrative Files; (2) Concert Files; (3) Concert Management and Booking Files; (4) Concert Program Files; (5) Publicity and Advertising; (6) Marketing Files; (7) Broadcast Media Associate Files and Media Relations/In Recital Files; (8) Performance Files; (9) Miscellaneous Materials: Scrapbooks, Miscellaneous Signed Photographs, Artwork Assigned to Scrapbooks; (10) Concert Recordings. Sub-Series have been established for audio and video recordings.

In general, the original order of materials has been maintained to provide a contextual relationship of individual items within each series and within the total collection. Although many of the files were originally organized either alphabetically or chronologically, there seem to be inconsistencies in the filing systems used by the Ambassador personnel. Filing procedures within a single office appeared to have changed over time, or in some cases it appears that different filing systems were used simultaneously. To a large degree, these variants in filing procedure have been maintained with occasional small adjustments made to group together certain related materials when it made sense to do so.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ambassador Auditorium is located on the grounds of Maranatha High School (formerly the campus of Ambassador College) in Pasadena, California. The Ambassador was built under the guidance of Herbert W. Armstrong as a facility for religious services of the Worldwide Church of God and also as a performing arts center. The architectural design of the building bears certain similarities to that of the Temple of ancient Israel.

The first public concert at the Ambassador was presented by the Vienna Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Carlo Maria Giulini, on April 7, 1974. For the next twenty years the Ambassador hosted many of the world’s finest performing artists in many genres, and thus it was known as “The Carnegie Hall of the West.” Notable artists who performed at the Ambassador included Artur Rubinstein, Leontyne Price, Victor Borge, Peter Schickele as P.D.Q. Bach, Julian Bream, Andrés Segovia, Barbara Cook, Juilliard String Quartet, Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, Yo-Yo Ma, Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Bing Crosby, Bob Hope, the Chieftains, the Kingston Trio, Emmylou Harris, Alison Krauss, Marcel Marceau, Claire Bloom, Count Basie, Benny Goodman, Modern Jazz Quartet, Oscar Peterson, Ravi Shankar, Mel Tormé, and the Dance Theatre of Harlem. During this period the Ambassador also hosted the inaugural Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition as well as the Pasadena Jazz Festival.
The interior design of the hall was noted for its exceptional elegance displaying Iranian onyx, African teak wood, gold overlay and wool carpets from India. Due to the relatively small seating capacity of the main hall with 1262 seats (compared with Carnegie Hall’s Isaac Stern Auditorium which has 2804 seats), the Ambassador was particularly well suited to small ensembles and solo performances.
In the mid 1990s the Worldwide Church of God, which operated the Ambassador Auditorium and Ambassador College, ceased its operations and sold the property. In 2004 a portion of the property, including the Ambassador Auditorium, was purchased by HRock Church of Pasadena.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Listening appointments may require 24 hours notice. Contact the Archive Operations Manager.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ambassador Auditorium Collection, ARS.0043. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, CA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ambassador Auditorium Collection was assembled and donated by the Ambassador Foundation in 2001. The collection consists of over 600 boxes of concert information and documentation from the numerous files of the Ambassador Auditorium during the period of April 1974 through May 1995. The materials include concert program booklets, concert and promotional audio and video recordings, concert season planning materials, artist publicity materials, individual event files, posters, photographs, scrapbooks, original artwork used for publicity, and so far is as known, the complete office files from the various departments of the Ambassador Auditorium including some correspondence and inter-office memos.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The Administrative Files contain a mixture of paper and photographic materials and a variety of audio and video recordings. Some recordings document performances that took place at the Ambassador Auditorium, and for those recordings program information has been provided when it was available.

did.physdesc: 77 audio cassettes ; 34 5" open reel tapes ; 5 7" open reel tapes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audio cassette and open reel tapes containing radio promotional spots for numerous artists who appeared at the Ambassador. Some tapes are labeled for broadcast on specific Southern California radio stations, including KABC, KAJZ/KBJZ, K-BIG, KCRW, KCSN, KFAC, K-FROG, KFWB, KGIL, KIK, KKGO, KLSX, KNX, KSKQ, KTWV, KUSC, KXEZ, and KZLA. The majority of the tapes contain the name of the performance being advertised, and some tapes are also labeled with date information and/or the length of the radio spot(s).
NB: One audio cassette tape containing a radio promotional spot for Mr. Jack Daniel's Original Silver Cornet Band was removed from Series 5, Box 180, Folder 6.180.9 and relocated in this box.

arrangement.p: These audio recordings are boxed together with audio cassette tapes of Ambassador performances (the two groups of materials have been clearly separated within the box). For a description of the performance tapes, see Box 601 in Series 10.

did.unittitle: Audio Recordings: Demo/Promotional and Radio Interviews and Performances:
did.physdesc: 153 audio cassettes ; 5 7" open reel tapes ; 3 DATs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The recordings in this box are divided into two categories. Placed on top within the box are 3 DATs (digital audio tapes) and 43 audio cassettes. These recordings consist of radio programs and interviews broadcast on various stations, including KCRW, KFAC, KGIL, KJOI, KKGO, KLON, KPCC, KPFK, KUSC, WBGO, and WQXR. Interviewers and radio personalities represented include Jerry Bishop (KGIL), Gail Eichenthal, Bonnie Grice (KUSC), Greg Hettmansberger (NPR’s “Performance Today”), Isabel Holt, Fred Hyatt, Branford Marsalis (JazzSet), Duff Murphy (KPCC), Chuck Niles, John Santana (KKGO’s “In the Wings”), Tom Schnabel (KCRW), John Schneider (KPFK), Judith Schonbach (NPR’s “Morning Edition”), Chuck Southcott (KJOI), and Jim Svedja (KUSC). Artists featured and/or interviewed include Donald Adams, Cecilia Bartoli, Valentin Berlinsky (Borodin Quartet), Teresa Brewer, Chick Corea, Gary Crosby, Anne-Sophie Mutter (Mutter did not perform at the Ambassador, though she was included in the proposed 1995-1996 concert season, which did not take place), Pasadena Jazz Festival performers (Dori Caymmi, Clayton-Hamilton Jazz Orchestra, Benny Green, Ken Peplowski, Frank Vignola, and Rickey Woodard), the Pied Pipers, Ivo Pogorelich, Pogorelich Competition contestants (Edith Chen, Michael Kieran Harvey, Irina Plotnikova, Evgeny Zarafiants), Pepe Romero, Richard Sheldon, and Billy Taylor.

The other 110 cassettes and 5 7" open reel tapes in the box are miscellaneous demo or promotional recordings by various artists, arranged roughly in alphabetical order according to performer name (This box contains the sequence A - D; D - N is located in Box 603 and N - Z in Box 604). Some of the artists represented in these recordings performed at the Ambassador, though the majority did not.
NB: One promotional audio cassette tape (Bulgarian Women's Choir: Le Mystere Des Voix Bulgares, Vol. Two) was removed from Series 5, Box 141, Folder 5.141.1 and relocated in this box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 133 cassettes in this box are miscellaneous commercial, demonstration and promotional recordings by various artists, arranged roughly in alphabetical order according to performer name. Some of the artists represented in these recordings performed at the Ambassador, though the majority did not. The box also contains 2 empty cassette cases with labeled inserts (j-cards).

did.unittitle: Audio Recordings: Performances, Demo/Promotional, Radio Programs, and Miscellaneous:
did.physdesc: 139 audio cassettes ; 5 5" open reel tapes ; 1 tape box containing an empty reel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains 139 cassette tapes, including 74 tapes that are recordings of performances at the Ambassador arranged in chronological order from 01-13-1987 to 04-21-1988. These tapes are identified below by date and performer(s). The remaining 65 cassette tapes consist of performances made at venues other than the Ambassador, demonstration/promotional tapes, radio programs, and other miscellaneous recordings. These tapes are arranged in chronological order from 11-07-1976 to 01-07-1987, followed by undated tapes arranged alphabetically by the name of the performer. The box also contains five 5" open reel tapes and one tape box containing an empty 5" reel. These open reel tapes contain radio promotional spots for performances at the Ambassador that took place between 1987 and 1990; the empty tape box is labeled with information about the lacking tape.

did.unittitle: Audio Recordings: "In Recital at Ambassador" Radio Program and Miscellaneous:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 81 cassette tapes and 54 DATs in this box are recordings of public radio programs related to the Ambassador and performances at the Ambassador, along with other miscellaneous recordings. The bulk of the tapes document the public radio program "In Recital at Ambassador," produced by KUSC in Los Angeles and hosted by Beverly Sills. The program featured 39 performances recorded at the Ambassador between 1991 and 1994, over the course of three concert seasons. The majority of the tapes that contain recordings of this program are identified by four-digit numbers assigned by the Ambassador organization. Other tapes are identified by date and performer(s). Unless otherwise noted, each performance is represented by one cassette or DAT. A folder in the box contains program listings for all three seasons of “In Recital at Ambassador” with specific information about the performances featured in each radio program and promotional photographs of the performing artists and ensembles.

did.unittitle: Video Recordings (U-matic, Beta, VHS): Demo/Promotional, Performances, and Miscellaneous:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 29 video cassettes (6 U-matic, 5 Beta, and 18 VHS) in this box are miscellaneous demos, performances, promotional spots, and other types of video works by various artists, including travelogues and commercially released performance tapes. The VHS tapes are grouped roughly in alphabetical order according to performer name (This box contains the VHS sequence A - B; B - K is located in Box 606 and K - Z in Box 607). Some of the artists represented in these recordings performed at the Ambassador.

The tapes are grouped roughly in alphabetical order according to performer name (This box contains the VHS sequence B - K; A - B is located in Box 605, along with Beta and U-matic tapes, and L - Z in Box 607). Some of the artists represented in these recordings performed at the Ambassador.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 399, 400, 401 and 402 each contain miscellaneous video materials, including promotional spots, television appearances, interviews/news programs, and recordings of performances that took place at the Ambassador as well as other venues. Some of the recordings are undated and contain limited information, and some but not all of the performers featured on these tapes appeared at the Ambassador. The artists and ensembles represented include Jorge Bolet, Victor Borge, the Chieftains, Dance Theatre of Harlem, Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, the Paper Bag Players, Jean-Pierre Rampal, the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, Artur Rubinstein, and Robert Shields, among others. These materials have been arranged generally by format. This box (399) contains 15 U-matic video tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 399, 400, 401 and 402 each contain miscellaneous video materials, including promotional spots, television appearances, interviews/news programs, and recordings of performances that took place at the Ambassador as well as other venues. Some of the recordings are undated and contain limited information, and some but not all of the performers featured on these tapes appeared at the Ambassador. The artists and ensembles represented include Jorge Bolet, Victor Borge, the Chieftains, Dance Theatre of Harlem, Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, the Paper Bag Players, Jean-Pierre Rampal, the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, Artur Rubinstein, and Robert Shields, among others. These materials have been arranged generally by format. This box (400) contains 10 U-matic video tapes and 6 open reel tapes (five tapes are 1” tape on 6 1/2” reels and one is 1" tape on an 8” reel).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Some of the recordings are undated and contain limited information, and some but not all of the performers featured on these tapes appeared at the Ambassador. The artists and ensembles represented include Jorge Bolet, Victor Borge, the Chieftains, Dance Theatre of Harlem, Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, the Paper Bag Players, Jean-Pierre Rampal, the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, Artur Rubinstein, and Robert Shields, among others. Three tapes are notable because they appear to be recordings that are not represented elsewhere in the collection. These are as follows:

01-23-1983: [1 Beta video cassette] Roger Bryant, tenor; Ruth Walter, piano; Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (L.A.C.O.); Gerard Schwarz, director/conductor: [NB: Multiple audio recordings of this performance can be found in boxes 481, 482, and 524; for program information, see Tapes (8304:1-2), Box 524]

10-17-1987: [1 Beta video cassette labeled "Audio only digital"] James Galway, flute; Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (L.A.C.O.); Ransom Wilson, conductor/flute: Handel, George Frideric, 1685-1759. Solomon. Sinfonia -- Haydn, Joseph, 1732-1809. Symphonies, H. I, 42, D major -- Mozart, Wolfgang Amadeus, 1756-1791. Concertos, oboe, orchestra, K. 314, C major; arr. -- Cimarosa, Domenico, 1749-1801. Concertos, flutes (2), orchestra, G major -- Mercadante, Saverio, 1795-1870. Concertos, flute, orchestra, op. 57, E minor

10-25-1987: [1 VHS cassette; titles from program] The Great Gershwin Concert: Mel Tormé; Leslie Uggams; Peter Nero: Variations on I got rhythm -- Popular songs before Gershwin -- Early Gershwin medley -- Gershwin and love -- His concert music -- Great Gershwins -- Porgy and Bess in concert -- Playing up a Gershwin storm -- Cocktail party -- Ira and others -- The lost Gershwins -- Finale: more great Gershwins

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Files (1974 Inaugural Concert, Comments from Patrons and Performers, and Various Other Files):

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain a wide range of material dated from the 1970s through the 1990s that appears to have come from different sources within the Ambassador organization. Folders 1-7 contain material related to the Inaugural Concert and dedication of the Auditorium held in April of 1974; folders 13-18 contain a variety of comments and letters regarding the Ambassador from patrons, performers, and the local community.

[Folders:] (1) Vienna Symphony Concert (Carlo Maria Giulini, conductor) held April 7, 8, and 9, 1974 [miscellaneous, including 1993 correspondence regarding concert video footage being transferred to VHS tape, scripts from radio broadcast of Vienna Symphony concert and 1975 Rubinstein concert]; (2) Vienna Symphony Concert [miscellaneous, including German press kit for Vienna Symphony, ticket requests, luncheon invitations, general invitation, pre-concert preparation]; (3) Vienna Symphony Performance [Carlo Maria Giulini]; (4) Carlo Maria Giulini; (5) Vienna Symphony Concert [miscellaneous, including program notes, ticketing, parking arrangements, hotel arrangements, publicity/press release materials]; (6) Vienna Symphony Concert [expenditure report, videotaping, correspondence, plans for opening, 1972-1975]; (7) Vienna Symphony Concert [auditorium dedication: guests, media coverage, and miscellaneous correspondence]; (8) Artur Rubinstein [concert], January 15, 1975; (9) DMJM [Daniel, Mann, Johnson and Mendenhall] Auditorium Architects, Two articles [on concert hall acoustics], 10th Anniversary Announcement; (10-11) Andrew York Benefit ["From the Heart," concert for his wife Barbie York], 04-27-1992; (12) Los Angeles Children's Chorus, 06-01-1992; (13) Miscellaneous good comments [patrons and performers, 1989-1995]; (14-16) Patron, performer, and community comments and letters [1990-1995]; (17) Patron comments and letters [1978-1979, 1986]; (18) Children's letters and comments [1977-1979]; (19) Proposed Gold Medal Series on Angel Records [1985-1986]; (20) Max Herman - American Federation of Musicians [1975-1980]; (21) Life Members Symphony Orchestra Concert for Public Schools [1979-1983]; (22) Memos - Clifford Greck [1979-1981]; (23) [Memos] Robert Kuhn [1977-1978]; (24) ISPAA [International Society of Performing Arts Administrators] Luncheon, 06-21-1991 [Henry Mancini and Herb Alpert, award recipients]; (25) ISPAA/Ambassador Foundation International Award Project [1988-1990].

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Files ("Heidi," UK/LA festival, and Various Other Materials):

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain various materials dated from 1975 through 1988. Folders 2-10 contain material related to the production of "Heidi" from the 1976-1977 season.

[Folders:] (1) [Miscellaneous newsletters and programs, 1975-1988]; (2-3) "Heidi" 1976-1977 [miscellaneous records]; (4-5) "Heidi" 1976-1977 [cast and cast contracts]; (6) "Heidi" 1976-1977 [production records]; (7) "Heidi" 1976-1977 [study guides]; (8-10) "Heidi" 1977 Children's Responses [letters and drawings from children who attended performances of "Heidi" at the Ambassador]; (11-12) UK/LA 1988 [Arts festival].

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Files (Correspondence and Various Other Materials):

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain a range of material dated from 1974 to 1987.

[Folders:] (1) [Lists of 2-track and 4-track performance recordings made at Ambassador, 1974-1984]; (2) Ambassador Auditorium Rental [requests and correspondence, 1977-1983]; (3-4) Favorable comments [correspondence regarding the Ambassador from patrons, performers, and the local community], 1976-1987; (5-9) Correspondence [miscellaneous], 1975-1985; (10) [Correspondence and clippings, 1974-1983]; (11) Correspondence, 1976-1984; (12) [Response papers from students at John Muir High School regarding the performance of Leon Bates, 1983-1984]; (13-14) AC [Ambassador College] Music Department, Tickets purchased (1982-1983) and half-price tickets; (15-16) ISPAA [International Society of Performing Arts Administrators] Archives Files (1978-1985); (17) WAAA [Western Alliance of Arts Administrators] Conference Files (1979-1984); (18-19) Performing Arts Memos (1977-1986).

scopecontent.p: These files contain materials related to the 1995 Ambassador Award for Excellence given to Mel Tormé (folders 1-5), as well as a variety of other materials from multiple concert seasons in the early 1990s.

[Folders:] (1) 1995 Award for Excellence [recipient was Mel Tormé]: Articles, memos, correspondence; (2) Award for Excellence: Reception shot list, guest list; (3) Award for Excellence: Fact sheets, press release; (4) Award for Excellence: Proofs and photographs; (5) Award for Excellence: Schedule, fact sheets, Ambassador logos; (6-7) [ISPAA (International Society of Performing Arts Administrators) files]; (8) PIRATES [Public Interest Radio and Television Educational Society]; (9) 1992 Telephone Directory; (10) Harolyn Blackwell, biography/reviews/photos; (11) Roy Clark, biography/reviews/photos; (12) City of Los Angeles; (13) Donor Listing; (14) [International Events Group]; (15) [International Events Group, Sponsorship '91 Workbook]; (16) [International Events Group, Sponsor's Impact Workbook}; (17) Free Concerts, 1994-1995; (18) Young Musicians Foundation; (19) USC Rental [Daniel] Lewis Farewell [Concert]; (20) LACO [Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra]; (21) Audience Profile Study.

Two inventories in three-ring binders: (1) Ambassador Performing Arts Archives Inventory; (2) Miscellaneous Lists of Audio Recordings. NB: Photocopies of these two inventories are also kept in the Archive of Recorded Sound vertical files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audio and video recordings submitted in the application packages of participants in the Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition held in December of 1993, consolidated by format and arranged alphabetically by name in two boxes. The majority of these materials appear to be dubbed copies of recordings submitted by participants and are labeled only with the name of the participant, lacking any other information. All other application materials submitted by each participant can be found in Boxes 610 and 611.

Box 1: Two compact discs: Edmund Battersby [both are commercial releases on Koch International Classics: Preludes and etudes tableaux from opus 23, 32 & 39 / Rachmaninoff, Sergei, 1873-1943 (3-7098-2H1), and Goyescas / Granados, Enrique, 1867-1916 ; Tonadas / Nin-Culmell, Joaquín, 1908-2004 (3-7062-2H1)]. One VHS cassette tape: Iwan Konig ; one VHS cassette tape: Irina Plotnikova. Ten audio cassette tapes [Unless otherwise noted, each participant is represented by one cassette.]: Eteri Andjaparidze; Sergei Babayan [2 cassettes]; James Barbagallo; Olivier Cazal; Edith Chen; Irina Chukovsky; Mia Chung; Noel Engebretson; Michael Kieran Harvey.

Box 2: Thirty-eight audio cassette tapes [Unless otherwise noted, each participant is represented by one cassette.]: Michael Kieran Harvey; Gaetano Indaco; Michael Injae Kim; Mikhail Kollontay; Iwan Konig [2 cassettes]; Avo Kuyumjian; Leonid Kuzmin [2 cassettes]; Thomas Labé; Daniel Lessner; Michael Lewin [2 cassettes]; Jura Margulis [2 cassettes]; Steven Mayer [3 cassettes; dropped out]; Masako Nakai; Gregorio Nardi; John Novacek; Peter Orth [2 cassettes]; Andrea Padova; Artur Papazian; Dmitri Ratser [2 cassettes]; Corrado Rollero; Neil Rutman; Paul Shaw; Aleksei Takenouchi [2 cassettes]; Oleg Volkov; Volodymyr Vynnytsky [dropped out]; Mark Westcott [2 cassettes]; Serghei Yerokhin; Evgeny Zarafiants.

scopecontent.p: This box contains five award statues--a gold sculpture representing the Grand Prix Award, a silver sculpture representing Second Prize, two bronze sculptures representing Third Prize, and a prototype sculpture--from the Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition in separate cases. separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Two oversize items (Kirov Ballet materials) were removed from Box 290 (they were originally laid across the top of folders in the box) and relocated to Series 9, Box 416 (miscellaneous separated materials), Folder 2.290.1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The ten folders in this box all contain materials related to performances by the Kirov Ballet that took place in May of 1986. These materials may include programs, correspondence, contracts, press kits, clippings, reviews, photographs, fliers and other promotional/publicity material. Additional materials include souvenir books and program inserts, items related to the opening night dinner, tickets and ticket sales, insurance, security, and production budget. Folder (1) contains a cross reference form for oversized items that were removed and relocated with other oversize materials. These items are the Los Angeles Times "Calendar" dated 05-18-1986 and a collection of photocopies of newspaper articles from the same time period related to the Kirov Ballet.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

Thus, the materials are grouped into two distinct series.

scopecontent.p: Folders contain various materials including programs, correspondence, contracts, clippings, reviews, photographs, fliers, and other records related to concert performances from the 1993-1994 Season and the 1994 Pasadena Jazz Festival, along with records related to other features of the Jazz Festival, such as the sale of food and souvenirs. controlaccess.corpname: American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert Program Files consist of 21 boxes of files which include copies of concert programs from the inaugural concert, 04-07-1974, through the final concert, 05-21-1995, as well as copies of information sources used by the editor to create the programs. Editor's reference materials include artists' biographical and promotional information, photographs, editor's working copies of programs, miscellaneous informational materials, and Newsletters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Original order of the materials in the collection has been maintained as much as possible. Program booklets are arranged in chronological order. Accompanying materials pertaining to specific concert programs are placed with the related program booklets. Other materials not associated with a specific concert program are filed at the end of the associated concert season or housed in boxes of miscellaneous materials that follow the chronologically arranged materials. Individual arrangement notes have been provided for boxes which contain exceptions to the general arrangement procedure.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Items are arranged in the following order: Program books for TV Specials (1976-1981); Early Benefits (1977-1983); Scott Church Choir and Orchestra (1977); Concert program files in chronological order: Inaugural Concert, 04-07-1974; concerts from January 1975 through September 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Souvenir booklets for TV specials of the Cardiac League and Assistance League of Pasadena; early benefit performances of Scott Church Choir and Orchestra. Inaugural concert programs from April 7, 1974 concert and other early concert programs. Program booklets from January 1975 through September 1980. Also miscellaneous program pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the following Seasons: 1980-1981, 1981-1982 and the first half of the 1982-1983 Season. Date range of program booklets is 10-1980 through 01-1983. Includes one folder of photocopies of miscellaneous pages from program booklets dating from 10-07-1978 through 06-16-1981. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts dating from 02-1983 through 04-1984. Includes one folder of the Master Calendar of all Ambassador Auditorium events from 04-07-1974 through 12-13-1983. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts from 04-1984 through 12-1985. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts from 01-1986 through 01-1988. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in most of the 1987-88 Season and the entire 1988-89 Season. Date range of program booklets is 12-1987 through 06-1989. No related biographical or repertoire information included in folders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in the following order: (1) Newsletters; (2) World Travel Series; (3) Regular Concert Programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Newsletters (2 folders): Performing Arts News, v.1, n.1-v.6, n.3 (1980-1986); Virtuoso, v.1, n.1-v.6, n.3 (1989-1995). Includes note stating "there was a period of hiatus when no newsletters were published. [Performing Arts News] was later reactivated as 'Virtuoso.'" (2) World Travel Series program booklets (1 folder). (3) Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the first half of the 1989-1990 Season. Date range of program booklets is 09-17-1989 through 01-29-1990. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the last half of the 1989-1990 Season and the first half of the 1990-1991 Season. Date range of program booklets is 01-29-1990 through 11-18-1990. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders. Includes one miscellaneous program from a non-regular concert of the Pasadena Youth Symphony Orchestra.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the 1990-1991 Season. Date range of program booklets is 11-28-1990 through 04-29-1991. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Concert Program files are arranged in chronological order. One folder with material from a cancelled performance from the 1990-1991 Season is filed at the end of that Season (Folder 4-10-12).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts at the end of the 1990-1991 Season and beginning of the 1991-1992 Season. Date range of program booklets is 04-30-1991 through 02-13-1992. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in chronological order from 02-15-1992 through 11-09-1992. Six folders of material about cancelled performances are at the end of the chronological sequence in the box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the last half of the 1991-1992 Season and the first half of the 1992-1993 Season. Date range of program booklets is 02-15-1992 through 11-09-1992. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders. Includes 6 folders of information about cancelled programs from the 1991-1992 season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the 1992-1993 Season. Date range of program booklets is 11-11-1992 through 05-02-1993. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the last half of the 1992-1993 Season and the first half of the 1993-1994 Season. Date range of program booklets is 05-04-1993 through 02-09-1994. Folders also contain related biographical and promotional materials. Many items have handwritten comments related to the performers, the repertoire or other matters. Some folders contain performer photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts in the last half of the 1993-1994 Season and the beginning of the 1994-1995 Season. Date range of program booklets is 02-10-1994 through 10-23-1994. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts through most of the 1994-1995 Season. Date range of program booklets is 10-24-1994 through 03-04-1995. Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Concert program booklets from regularly scheduled concerts through the end of the 1994-1995 Season. Date range of program booklets is 03-06-1995 through 05-21-1995, with two additional booklets from cancelled concerts scheduled to be held 10-22-1994 and 03-30-1995 (32 folders). Related biographical and repertoire information included in folders. (2) Program booklets, related biographical and repertoire information, advertising and promotional material, and other general material having to do with the Pasadena Jazz Festival (14 folders). Date range of materials is from 08-1991 to 08-1994 (the Festival took place in August each year).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in the following order: concert programs and general material from the end of Season 1994-1995 filed in chronological order (16.1-16.32); two folders with material from cancelled performances from the 1994-1995 Season are filed at the end of that Season (Folders 4.16.31 and 4.16.32); programs and other materials from the Pasadena Jazz Festival filed in chronological order, with dividers inserted between folders in keeping with original filing order.

did.unittitle: Concert and Event Materials; Marketing, Programming, and Promotional Materials; Award for Excellence Files:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in the following order, with dividers inserted between folders in keeping with original filing order: two special issues of "Virtuoso" newsletter from 12-1990 with separate marketing and programming surveys, survey results, and other related material; ticket samples, 1977-1984; Award for Excellence Files, 1991-1994; fact sheets, 1994; concert and event programs and general promotional materials roughly in chronological order, 1974-1978; program and autographed photographs of Pearl Bailey, 02-09-1978; separated materials.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Folder 4-17-26 contains a cross reference form for posters and promotional material originally laid across the top of the folders in this box. These materials were relocated to Series 9, Box 416 (miscellaneous separated materials), Folder 4-17-1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Two special issues of "Virtuoso" newsletter from 12-1990 containing separate marketing and programming audience surveys, survey results, and other related material, including surveys carried out by other organizations (3 folders). (2) Samples of tickets from concerts and events, 1977-1984 (1 folder). (3) Award for Excellence Files, including photographs, biographical and publicity material, 1991-1994. Recipients include Arthur Mitchell (1991), Sam Wanamaker (1991), Placido Domingo (1992), Ivo Pogorelich (1993), and Leontyne Price (1994) (6 folders). (4) Ambassador Performing Arts fact sheet, 06-1994 (1 folder). (5) Concert and event programs, event calendars, and general promotional materials related to performances and events held at the Auditorium (13 folders). Date range is from 04-1974 through 09-1978. Folder 4-17-13 contains programs from Inaugural Concert Season 1975-1976. Folder 4-17-22 contains program and related materials for 12-15-1977 event, Gene Kelly - An American in Pasadena. (6) Pearl Bailey program from 02-09-1978 with photographs autographed by Bailey (1 folder, 4-17-25). (7) Cross reference form detailing oversize material (posters and promotional material) separated from box 17 (1 folder, 4-17-26).

did.unittitle: Concert and Event Materials with Promotional Material from 1978-1979 through 1980-1981 Seasons:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in the following order, in keeping with original order of the materials: security ID buttons from Bob Hope show, 01-04-1979; three-ring binder containing script from Ford Anniversary show, July-August 1978; one folder of concert and event materials, 05-1978 to 12-1978; materials from 1978 Invitational Chess Championship Tournament, 06-04, 05-1978; concert and event material, with some folders also containing promotional material, roughly in chronological order from 01-1978 to 01-1980; three scripts (first draft and two copies of final draft, one with annotation) from "Hope, Women and Song," a special featuring Bob Hope and guests, 12-1979 to 01-1980; concert and event material, with some folders also containing promotional material, roughly in chronological order from 01-1980 to 09-1981 (this sequence includes a single folder of material related to a Boys Club of Pasadena/Narconon concert held 5-21-1980).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Security ID buttons from Bob Hope show, 01-04-1979, in sealed envelope (Folder 4.18.1). (2) Script in three-ring binder for Ford 75th Anniversary show, "A Salute to American Imagination," July-August, 1978 (Folder 4.18.2). (3) Folder labeled "Information, fliers, etc. disseminated at 1978 Invitational Chess Championship Tournament, 06-04, 05-1978" (Folder 4.18.4). (4) Twelve folders of concert and event materials (such as fliers, handbills, program inserts, calendars, postcards, etc.), which may include programs for events held at the Auditorium that were not part of the regular performance season (such as commencement or award ceremonies, recitals, dance performances, performances by Ambassador College groups, etc.), in addition to other promotional material (booklets, brochures, pamphlets, photographs, etc.), roughly in chronological order with dates that range from 01-1978 to 09-1981. (5) Materials related to Boys Club of Pasadena/Narconon D.A.W.N. (Drug Awareness with Narconon) concert held 05-12-1981 (Folder 4.18.16). (6) Three scripts (one first draft and two copies of final draft, one with annotations) from "Hope, Women and Song," a special filmed for television featuring Bob Hope and guests, 12-1979 to 01-1980, air date 01-21-1980 (Folders 4.18.11-13).

did.unittitle: Concert and Event Materials with Promotional Material from 1981-1982 through 1983-1984 Seasons:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders arranged in the following order, in keeping with original order of the materials: concert and event materials, May-June 1981; script, first draft, Second Annual Listen America Pageant, 06-1981; concert and event materials, 06-1981 to 04-1982; three folders of NASA materials with dates ranging from 1976-1981; four folders of concert and event materials, dates ranging from 10-1981 to 06-1983; pictures distributed at Sherrill Milnes recital, 01-20-1983; concert and event materials, 12-1982 to 03-1983; Mummenschanz promotional materials, 04-24-1983; concert and event materials, 1982-1983 season; script, second draft, "Here's Television Entertainment," 06-23-1983; concert and event materials, 1983-1984 season.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Nine folders of concert and event materials (such as fliers, handbills, program inserts, calendars, postcards, etc.), which may include programs for events held at the Auditorium that were not part of the regular performance season (such as commencement or award ceremonies, recitals, dance performances, performances by Ambassador College groups, etc.), in addition to other promotional material (booklets, brochures, pamphlets, photographs, etc.), roughly in chronological order with dates ranging from 05-1981 to 01-1984. (2) First draft of script from Second Annual Listen America Pageant, dated 06-22-1981 (event was held on 06-25-1981)(Folder 4.19.2). (3) Three folders of NASA materials including educational publications on such topics as the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (located in Pasadena), Voyager 1, Voyager 2, Viking, the Space Shuttle, and Project Galileo, with dates ranging from 1976-1981 (Folders 4.19.4-6). (4) Folder of photographs (6 head shots) distributed at Sherrill Milnes recital, 01-20-1983 (Folder 4.19.11). (5) Mummenschanz promotional materials, including a t-shirt, button, and booklet, from performance held 04-24-1983 (Folder 4.19.13). (6) Second draft of script for "Here's Television Entertainment," event held 06-23-1983 (taped performance aired on NBC 12-04-1983)(Folder 4.19.15).

did.unittitle: Concert and Event Materials with Promotional Material from 1983-1984 through 1989-1990 Seasons:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged in keeping with original order of the materials, roughly in chronological order by season. Contents of individual folders (concert and event material with promotional material) may not be in exact chronological order.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Folder 4.20.8 contains cross reference form for two copies of a program for the Taipei Municipal Chinese Classical Orchestra from 1986 originally laid along one side of this box. These materials were relocated to Series 9, Box 416 (miscellaneous separated materials), Folder 4.20.1. Folder 4.20.5 contains cross reference form for one audio cassette and one video tape both labeled Press Release Herbert W. Armstrong and dated 01-16-1986. These materials were relocated with similar material formats in Series 10, Box 37.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Thirteen folders of concert and event materials (such as fliers, handbills, program inserts, calendars, postcards, etc.), which may include programs for events held at the Auditorium that were not part of the regular performance season (such as commencement or award ceremonies, recitals, dance performances, performances by Ambassador College groups, etc.), in addition to other promotional material (booklets, brochures, pamphlets, photographs, etc.), roughly in chronological order with dates that range from 01-1984 to 02-1990. (2) One folder includes materials labeled "Press Release 01-16-86" related to the death of Herbert W. Armstrong. These items include photographs, programs, newspapers, and press material, as well as an audio cassette tape and a video tape that were separated from the print materials (Folder 4.20.5). (3) One folder contains cross reference form detailing oversize material (event program) separated from Box 20 (Folder 4.20.8).

did.unittitle: Concert and Event Materials with Promotional Material from 1988-1989 through 1994-1995 Seasons:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (1) Fourteen folders of concert and event materials (such as fliers, handbills, program inserts, calendars, postcards, etc.), which may include programs for events held at the Auditorium that were not part of the regular performance season (such as commencement or award ceremonies, recitals, dance performances, performances by Ambassador College groups, etc.), in addition to other promotional material (booklets, brochures, pamphlets, photographs, etc.), roughly in chronological order with dates that range from 03-1989 to 05-1995. Folder 4.21.3 includes pamphlets and brochures on alcohol and drug abuse. (2) Folder 4.21.6 contains 1990-1991 program for Ballet Van Vlaanderen [The Royal Ballet of Flanders] in Dutch. (3) Folder 4.21.7 contains 1979 book on Lúčnica [folk dance ensemble from the former Czechoslovakia, now the Lúčnica Slovak National Folklore Ballet].

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Folder 4.21.17 contains two cross reference forms, one for Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (L.A.C.O.)/Chrysler promotional material from May of 1993 and one for an undated book entitled Antologia de la Zarzuela (Origin and Evolution of the Zarzuela). These materials were relocated to Series 9, Box 416 (miscellaneous separated materials), Folders 4.21.1 and 4.21.2 respectively.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged in keeping with original order of the materials, roughly in chronological order by season. Contents of individual folders (concert and event material with promotional material) may not be in exact chronological order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Publicity and Advertising files have been maintained largely in the original order as received from the Ambassador Auditorium. The arrangement is in the order of concert seasons, and within each season the folders are arranged either alphabetically or chronologically.

did.unittitle: Chronological Files: Publicity and Advertising 1986-1987, 1987-1988, 1988-1989 Seasons:

scopecontent.p: Contents: Publicity materials from the 1986-1987, 1987-1988, and 1988-1989 seasons: (1) 1986-1987 season brochures, season announcements and publicity materials for the Gold Medal Series; (2) 1987-1988 advertisements in the LA Times, Pasadena Star, Pasadena Weekly, and Herald Examiner; (3) 1987-1988 news releases; (4) 1987-1988 and 1988-1989 Material Release Authorizations; (5) 1987-1988 imprinting files; (6) 1987-1988 season brochures; (7) 1987-1988 publicity requisition files; (8) 1987-1988 press assignments (duplicates); (9) 1988-1989 photography requests.

did.unittitle: Files for Brochures, Fliers, Postcards, Invitations and Other Mailings from 1983-1984, 1986-1987, 1987-1988, and 1988-1989 Seasons:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Original contents of each folder were divided into two folders with one containing print materials and photographs and the other containing plastic holders with color slides. Contents have been combined so that all materials for a single artist or event are contained within a single folder.
Original filing order of folders has been maintained, that is, alphabetical by name of artist, ensemble, or title of program.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Files in this box contain materials used in planning the proposed 1995-1996 concert season. Since the Ambassador Auditorium presented its final concert in May 1995, the 1995-1996 season did not occur. Thus, these files provide documentation of artists and events that were supposed to be part of the 1995-1996 season; however, the files do not represent events that actually took place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders originally labeled "Biography/Reviews/Photos" include artist biographical information, reviews, some correspondence and inter-office notes, publicity fliers, photographs and color slides. Some folders include press packets.
Names on folder labels have been transcribed as they originally appeared:

[Folders:] (1) Adair, Joe & May Liz: "Germany"; (2) Baltimore Consort; (3) Big Band Salute to Artie Shaw; (4) Blackwell, Harolyn; (5) Brazilian Masters: Charlie Byrd/ Laurindo Almeida/Carlos Barbosa-Lima; (6) Mr. Keith Brion's Big Top Band; (7) Chen, Edith; (8) Chilingirian Quartet; (9) Chick Corea; (10) Douglas, Barry; (11) Foster, Grant: "New Zealand Outdoor Adventure"; (12) Gold Rush Cornet Band; (13) Guarneri Quartet/Orion Quartet; (14) Guitar Summit: Steve Morse/Jorma Kaukonen/Manuel Barrueco/Kenny Burrell; (15) Nicola Hall; (16) Holod, John; (17) Camellia Johnson; (18) Jones, Doug; (19) Kim Josephson; (20) Juilliard Quartet; (21) Hae-Jung Kim; (22) King, Andrew L.; (23) LACO [Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra]/Iona Brown/Christoff Perrick; (24) Richard Leech; (25) Meng-Chieh Liu; (26) London Brass; (27) Glenn Miller Lives; (28) Millo, Aprile; (29) Mummenschanz; (30) Mutter, Anne Sophie; (31) National Band of New Zealand; (32) Jessye Norman; (33) Ohlsson, Garrick; (34) Operetta in Concert; (35) Paragon Ragtime Orchestra; (36) Rampal, Jean-Pierre; (37) Ratser, Dmitri; (38) Redman, Joshua; (39) Celino Romero; (40) Romeros; (41) Schiff, Andreas; (42) Solzhenitsyn, Ignat; (43) Tallis Scholars; (44) Tomsic, Dubravka; (45) Mel Tormé/George Shearing; (46) Vienna Choir Boys; (47) Williams, Robin; (48) Wilson, John; (49) York, Michael; (50) Zenith of the Big Horns: Joe Lovano/Craig Handy/James Moody/Ernie Watts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files on media coverage of the closing of Ambassador Auditorium, dating from the announcement made in January 1995 through the end of June 1995.

[Folders] (1) Letter/announcement sent to patrons and friends of the Ambassador; (2) Correspondence and record of phone calls received regarding closure; (3) Closure articles from David Hulme; (4) L.A. Times articles, 01-28-1995 to 05-28-1995; (5) Pasadena Star News, 01-28-1995 to 06-28-1995; (6) Articles/news reports from miscellaneous sources, 01-29-1995 to 06-1995; (7) Audio cassette tape recording labeled "Various Artist Comments," (Mel Tormé, Lee Ritenour, Roger Williams, Seldom Scene, and 15th Air Force Band); (8) Set of closure articles (originals); (9) Two complete sets of closure articles (copies); (10) Two copies of American Record Guide, May-June 1995 issue, with article about closing of Ambassador; (11) Press release, 01-27-1995; (12) Closure articles, originals, incomplete set.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles on the closing of the Ambassador Auditorium in chronological order. Includes newspaper segments from Daily Breeze/News Pilot, Los Angeles Times, Pasadena Star-News, Pasadena Weekly, Portfolio [Ambassador University, Big Sandy, TX], and one issue of Daily Variety.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains numerous galley proofs and other paper materials related to a two page Los Angeles Times ad for 1991-1992 Season subscriptions, 1991 IEG Sponsor ads, and season brochures for the 1992-1993 Season. The box also contains a 3 1/2" floppy disk housed in an envelope, along with the information retrieved from the disk, which consists of copy for the 1992-1993 subscription brochure. This information was printed and placed in the box with the disk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains galley proofs of season brochures for the 1993-1994 Season, Friends of Ambassador brochures, and Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (L.A.C.O.) brochures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains various publicity and advertising materials, including 9 oversize envelopes, 15 oversize photographic prints, and one oversize photographic color transparency. The prints are in color and black & white, and the majority are mounted on cardboard. Artists pictured in the photographs include the Benny Goodman Classical Trio (with Nathaniel Rosen and Leslie Howard), members of Dance Theatre of Harlem, Gelsey Kirkland, performers in "A Musical Jubilee" (Howard Keel, Larry Kert, Eartha Kitt, Patrice Munsel, Milo O'Shea), Valery and Galina Panov, members of the Rome Piccolo Opera, and Marianna Tcherkassky. Some photographs feature exterior and interior views of the Ambassador Auditorium. The envelopes contain materials such as galley proofs and film transparencies, specifically described as follows:

[Envelopes:] (1) 1992 Friends [of Ambassador] letter/envelope film; (2) GM [Gold Medal Series] Single Flier 1992-1993; (3) [Ivo] Pogorelich [International Solo Piano Competition] LAT [Los Angeles Times] ad, 1993; (4) IPISPC [Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition] Banner Mock Up, 1993; (5) IPISPC [Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition] PSN [Pasadena Star News, 1993; (6) 1993-1994 Ad shells; (7) 1994 PJF [Pasadena Jazz Festival] Newspaper ad; (8) 1994 Calendar of Events [galley proofs]; (9) 1994-1995 Pasadena Magazine ad.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains various publicity and advertising materials, including 1991 Pasadena Jazz Festival flier film [transparencies], design mock-ups for two issues of Virtuoso [newsletter] (v. 1, no. 1, Sept.-Nov. 1989 and v. 1, no. 2, Dec. 1989-Feb. 1990), and 24 oversize photographic prints of artists performing at the Ambassador. The prints are in color and black & white, and the majority are mounted on cardboard. Artists pictured in the photographs include Dame Janet Baker, Vladimir Horowitz, Jose Iturbi, Eugene Ormandy, Luciano Pavarotti, Leontyne Price, Artur Rubinstein, Beverly Sills, and Andre Watts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains galley proofs and other publicity and advertising materials for the following: Past subscription ads [1984-1990]; 1990-1991 Calendar of Events (galley proofs); 1991-1992 Calendar of Events (galley proofs); 1991-1992 Season Brochure; 1992 Revised Calendar of Events; 1991-1992 Season TV Spot [includes photographic prints and negatives]; 1990-1991 Sampler [Series]; 1990-1991 Los Angeles Times ad proofs; 1991-1992 Los Angeles Times ad proofs.

did.unittitle: Publicity Materials: Posters (Miscellaneous Performers, Performances and Events):
did.physdesc: 200 posters in a 21" x 25" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains approximately 200 posters of various sizes. The majority of the posters advertise performances sponsored by the Ambassador Foundation at the Ambassador Auditorium or the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. A small number of the posters feature artists or ensembles who performed at the Ambassador but the posters do not reference a specific venue or performance date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains 13 posters, the majority of which are printed on cardboard and advertise performances held at the Ambassador between 1977 and 1989. It also contains 13 folders housing a variety of advertising and publicity materials that include paste-ups, mechanicals, and other artwork.

[Folders:] (1) 1989-1990 Season Osborne Brothers flier; (2) 1990-1991 Season KUSC Chamber [Music] flier; (3) 1990-1991 Season Early Music Series flier; (4) 1990-1991 Season Gold Medal Series flier; (5) 1990-1991 Season Guitar Series ad; (6) 1990-1991 Season Sounds of Genius Series flier; (7) 1990-1991 Season Lee Ritenour flier; (8) 1990-1991 Season "Gotta Sing, Gotta Dance" flier; (9) 1990-1991 Season Ellis Marsalis & Marcus Roberts/Chick Corea Akoustic Band fliers; (10) Juilliard String Quartet/Billy Taylor Trio flier; (11) 1990-1991 Season Scott Hamilton flier; (12) 1991-1992 Season fliers, galley proofs, and miscellaneous artwork; (13) (oversize folder) Miscellaneous advertising [numerous paste-ups and mechanicals, 1981-1982 Season?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous advertising materials, including artwork, transparencies, negatives, mechanicals, paste-ups, and galley proofs, related to performances and events held at the Ambassador between 1979 and 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous advertising materials, including artwork, transparencies, negatives, mechanicals, paste-ups, and galley proofs, related to performances and events held at the Ambassador between 1979 and 1986.

did.physdesc: 21 folders + 28 mounted items in 1 21" x 25" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous advertising materials, including posters mounted on boards, mock-up advertisements, marked photographs, and sample printings of advertisements.

Folders: (1) James Whitmore, promotional photo, as Will Rogers; (2) Two miscellaneous color photo slides; (3) the Chieftains (1 photo slide); (4) Mstislav Rostropovich (2 color photos); (5) Rudolf Nureyev (marked color photos); (6) Piano (ad drawing); (7) Flower bouquet (ad drawing); (8) Glenn Miller (mock-up drawing); (9) Ambassador Auditorium, exterior (photo negatives); (10) Ambassador Auditorium (miscellaneous promotional materials for concert hall and Ambassador College); (11) Young Concert Artists: mock-up ads; (12) Dance Theatre of Harlem: mock-up ad; (13) Young Americans: mock-up ads; (14) Chet Atkins: poster mock-up; (15) Subscription ad transparency; (16) Stan Kenton poster; (17) Bank advertisement with tribute to Pearl Bailey; (18) 1976-1977 Season: mock-up ads; (19) 1977-1978 Season: miscellaneous ads and mock-ups; (20) 1980-1981 Season: mock-up ads; (21) 1981-1982 Season poster.

Individual mounted posters: Tex Beneke and Four Freshmen; James Whitmore; Mighty Clouds of Joy & the Fairfield Four; Shields and Yarnell; Crystal Gayle; Texas Piano Professors; Royal Regiments on Parade; Ivo Pogorelich International Solo Piano Competition; José Molina Bailes Españoles; Mazowsze; The Chieftains; Larry Elgart and His Orchestra: Hooked on Swing; Big Band Hit Parade: Gogi Grant; The Flying Karamazov Brothers: “Club Sandwich”; Connie Haines and The Pied Pipers: Salute to Artie Shaw; The Kings of Swing and Tonight Show All-Stars; Ballet Folclórico Nacional de México; “From the Heart”; Spectacular New Series of Three Great Artists: Mstislav Rostropovich, Vladimir Ashkenazy, Robert Merrill: ad mock-ups; Big Band Swing Festival: postcard mock-ups; 1977-1978 Season ad mock-ups; 1977-1978 Subscription poster; Big Band Series postcard mock-up; Martin Workman: ad mock-up; Los Angeles Ballet: poster mock-up; Young Concert Artists Series 1979: mock-up boards.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Items have been divided into two groups and within each group, kept in original order: (1) unmounted and fragile items are enclosed in 21 file folders; (2) individual mounted items.

did.physdesc: 47 individually mounted posters in 1 21" x 25" flat box

scopecontent.p: Individual, mounted posters for the following events (posters show month and day but not the year of performance):

The Mikado; The Gondoliers; Peking Acrobats; Antologia de la Zarzuela; Dance Theatre of Harlem (2 mounted posters, 1 unmounted); Stars of American Ballet; Gelsey Kirkland and Company; State Symphonic Kapelle of Moscow; Gilbert & Sullivan: H.M.S. Pinafore; B. J. Ward in “Stand Up Opera”; Central Ballet of China; Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan, conductor; Frankie Laine and Kay Starr; Kirov Ballet; Krasnayarsk Siberian Dance Company; Kárpatók; Frula; Battlefield Band and Michael Flatley Trio; St. Louis Symphony, Leonard Slatkin, conductor; Two Ladies of Broadway: Carol Channing and Rita Moreno; Stars of American Ballet (2 posters); Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra; Cinderella: Los Angeles Ballet; Bob Hope; Dennis Wayne’s Dancers; Gene Kelly; Swinging Big Band Dance Nights; Patty Andrews and Les Brown; Keith Brion and His New Sousa Band; New Four Preps; Jim Cullum Jazz Band; Philharmonic Orchestra of London, Giuseppe Sinopoli, conductor; Philadelphia Orchestra, Riccardo Muti, conductor; Riders in the Sky; Les Ballets Africains; Americus Brass Band; Juilliard String Quartet; The King’s Singers; Orchestra of St. Luke’s, André Previn, conductor; José Molina Bailes Españoles; Festival of the Nile; British Music Hall “London Follies”; Roger Williams and Orchestra; Coldstream Guards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pasadena Jazz Festival promotional souvenirs sold by the Ambassador: 2 necktie pins; 2 coffee mugs (1 black, 1 white); 4 sweat shirts (2 white, 1 blue, 1 black).

did.physdesc: 1 photograph album, 19 1/2" x 12 1/2" with 27 pages, in 17" x 21" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph album containing color and black and white prints documenting the Ambassador Auditorium from the beginning of its construction on 01-14-1972 through a lecture given by Yitzhak Rabin that took place on 04-03-1978. The album is covered in a brown leather-like material embossed in gold with the image of the Auditorium and the Roman numeral I. The album includes photographs of the Auditorium's exterior and interior, along with photographs of selected performers and speakers who appeared there, many of which are autographed. Three posters (two of which are alike) depicting models and sketches of the Auditorium made prior to its construction are laid in the album.

did.physdesc: 1 photograph album, 19 1/2" x 12 1/2" with 27 pages, in 17" x 21" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph album containing color and black and white prints documenting performances and events that took place at the Ambassador Auditorium from 04-24-1978 through 10-31-1982. The album is covered in a brown leather-like material embossed in gold with the image of the Auditorium and the Roman numeral II. The album includes photographs of selected performers and ensembles who appeared at the Ambasssador, many of which are autographed.

did.unittitle: Publicity Materials: Posters (Miscellaneous Performers, Performances and Events):

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains approximately 66 posters of various sizes with dates that range from 1975 to 1995. The majority of the posters advertise performances sponsored by the Ambassador Foundation at the Ambassador Auditorium or the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. Some of the posters feature artists or ensembles who performed at the Ambassador but the posters do not reference the venue or the performance date. Nearly all of the posters are printed on cardboard.

did.unittitle: Scrapbooks: Herbert von Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic:
did.physdesc: 2 scrapbooks, 12 1/2" x 14 1/2" with 28 pages each, in a 17" x 21" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two scrapbooks containing newspaper and magazine clippings related to Herbert von Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra and their performances at the Ambassador on October 27, 28, 30, and 31 of 1982. One scrapbook has a title page, 26 pages of clippings, and one blank page; the second scrapbook has 19 pages of clippings and 9 blank pages. Dates of the clippings range from 09-21-1982 to 11-08-1982. Publications from which clippings were taken include: Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Los Angeles Times, Valley Daily News, Pasadena Star-News, Register, San Diego Evening Tribune, San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco Examiner, and New York Magazine [clipping is incorrectly labeled as being from the New Yorker].

did.physdesc: 2 folders and 21 envelopes in a 17" x 21" flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains clippings in folders and publicity and advertising materials housed in envelopes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All materials in these folders are related to the 1993 Pasadena Jazz Festival, which was held at the Ambassador Auditorium on August 7 and 8, 1993. Folders 1-10 contain information about performers, including biographies, reviews and photographs. [Folders:] (1) Hendrik Meurkens; (2) Black Note [musical group]; (3) Dori Caymmi; (4) Ricardo Silveira; (5) Ivan Lins; (6) Clayton-Hamilton Jazz Orchestra; (7) Diane Schuur; (8) Trio Da Paz; (9) Dave & Don Grusin and Friends; (10) Ken Peplowski Quintet; (11) PSA's and press releases; (12-13) Reviews; (14) Free listings/Festival guides; (15) Ticket sales; (16) Print advertising; (17) Radio/TV advertising; (18) Direct mail/distribution; (19) July 1993 issues of Jazziz and Down Beat, with ads for the festival; (20) Flier; (21) Ticket promotions; (22) Restaurants; (23) Tablecards; (24) Survey; (25) Menu insert; (26) Donation to charity [Red Cross]; (27) Ticket insert; (28) Letterhead/envelopes; (29) Poster; (30) [Souvenirs and program:] Aprons, t-shirts, sweat shirts, lapel pins, visor, mugs, program book; (31) Street/Mall banners; (32) Media analysis/Ticket sales reports; (33) Miscellaneous; (34) Chuck Niles [KLON]; (35) Correspondence; (36-37) Survey results and comments.

did.unittitle: Dance Theatre of Harlem Photograph Files:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise noted, contents of folders consist solely of photographic materials, including prints, contact proof sheets, and negatives. In some folders, the proof sheets and negatives correspond according to matching printed labels or handwritten information on the negative enclosures and the back of the proof sheets. All folders contain materials related to Dance Theatre of Harlem (DTH) and/or its founders, Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook. The material in the folders is dated as follows: [Folders] (1-3) 1978-1982; (4-7) 1985; (8) 1978-1985 [includes copies of publicity photographs]; (9-10) 1986; (11-14) 1988; (15-16) 03-10-1988, performance and reception with Sammy Davis, Jr. [benefit event?]; (17) 1988 [includes copies of publicity photographs].

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Negatives, Signed Concert Programs, and In-House Reference Materials:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Folders:] (1-4) Copies of Ambassador Auditorium concert programs signed by various performers; Folder 6.214.3 contains programs from various performances by the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra (L.A.C.O.), including a bound set of signed programs from the 1987-88 season; (5-8) AICF copies, various negatives [includes negatives for promotional shots of various performers].

[Boxes:] (Both boxes contain in-house reference materials.) One box contains an index labeled "Composers of works performed at Ambassador," in typescript on index cards arranged alphabetically by composer. This index appears to include concerts held between 1975-1979. One box contains an index labeled "Artists who have appeared at Ambassador," in typescript on index cards arranged alphabetically by name of performer. This index appears to cover the period 1975-1985. A complete version of this indexed performer information (covering the period 1974-1995) is available with the printed inventory of the collection that is on file in the Archive of Recorded Sound.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Slides have been kept in original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains 2 three-ring binders that hold sheets housing 1360 photographic slides of performers associated with the Ambassador Auditorium. The majority of the performers made one or more appearances at the Ambassador, and the slides include promotional images as well as some images from Ambassador performances. The slides are generally in alphabetical order according to the name of the artist or ensemble, but some slides are mislabeled or misfiled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains six 35mm slide boxes housing color slides, the majority of which contain images of performers associated with the Ambassador Auditorium. Most of these performers made one or more appearances at the Ambassador, and the slides include images used for advertising and publicity purposes, as well as images from performances at the Ambassador. Some of the slides may contain images of well-known figures, such as General Omar Bradley and Paul Newman; also, some slides may contain images of the Ambassador Auditorium and the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. Within the boxes, the slides have been arranged in alphabetical order by name, separated by labeled dividers. A few inconsistencies exist in the Ambassador filing system, and those have been left unaltered (e.g., the Flying Karamazov Brothers are filed under the letter K).

The contents of the slide boxes are as follows: (box 1) 165 slides, letters A - B; (box 2) 164 slides, letter B; (box 3) 167 slides, letters B - C; (box 4) 178 slides, letters C - D; (box 5) 203 slides, letter D; (box 6) 157 slides, letters D - G.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Slides have been kept in original order.

arrangement.p: Slides have been kept in original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains two 35mm slide boxes housing color slides, the majority of which contain images of performers associated with the Ambassador Auditorium. Most of these performers made one or more appearances at the Ambassador, and the slides include images used for advertising and publicity purposes, as well as images from performances at the Ambassador. Some of the slides may contain images of well-known figures, such as General Omar Bradley and Paul Newman; also, some slides may contain images of the Ambassador Auditorium and the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. Within the boxes, the slides have been arranged in alphabetical order by name, separated by labeled dividers. A few inconsistencies exist in the Ambassador filing system, and those have been left unaltered (e.g., the Flying Karamazov Brothers are filed under the letter K).

The contents of the slide boxes are as follows: (box 19) 159 slides, letter Z and dividers labeled with miscellaneous headings, including "Dupes" (label on one divider); (box 20) 166 slides, miscellaneous, including "Rejects" (label on one divider).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Slides have been kept in original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders contain photographs signed by numerous artists who performed at the Ambassador arranged in alphabetical order, with the exception of folder 6.328.1, which contains general comments and letters written by patrons and performers. Photographs of ensembles that are signed only by the conductor or a featured soloist are filed alphabetically under the name of that person; photographs with multiple signatures are filed under the name of the ensemble. When two performers appeared together in concert, such as Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax, and the signatures of both performers are on a single photograph, the photograph may be filed under the name of either performer.

[Folders:] (1) Comments and letters from patrons and performing artists; (2) Autographed pictures, in alphabetical order beginning with the letter A; (3-4) Autographed pictures, B; (5) Autographed pictures, C; (6) Autographed pictures, D; (7) Autographed pictures, E-F; (8) Autographed pictures, G; (9) Autographed pictures, H; (10) Autographed pictures, I-J; (11) Autographed pictures, K; (12) Autographed pictures, L; (13-14) Autographed pictures, M; (15-16) Autographed pictures, N-P.

did.unittitle: Alphabetical Photograph Files (Signed by Artists) and Miscellaneous (Photographs, Slides, and Printed Materials):

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders 1-6 contain photographs signed by numerous artists who performed at the Ambassador arranged in alphabetical order. Photographs of ensembles that are signed only by the conductor or a featured soloist are filed alphabetically under the name of that person; photographs with multiple signatures are filed under the name of the ensemble. When two performers appeared together in concert, such as Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax, and the signatures of both performers are on a single photograph, the photograph may be filed under the name of either performer.

Folders 7-21 contain photographic and some printed paper materials covering a variety of performers and subjects related to the Ambassador, some of which were used in the creation of a 24-page color booklet entitled "Encore! A Vision to Reopen Ambassador Auditorium," produced in 2003. Folders 9-18 contain prints, contact proof sheets, and negatives. These materials appear to have been removed from their original locations in other parts of the collection and gathered together for the purpose of creating this publication. Two copies of this 11" by 11" booklet are underneath the folders at the bottom of the box.

[Folders:] (1) Autographed pictures, Q-R; (2-3) Autographed pictures, S; (4) Autographed pictures, T; (5) Autographed pictures, U-W; (6) Autographed pictures, X-Z and miscellaneous; (7) 159 slides of advertisements for Ambassador performances; (8) [List of photographic materials used in production of Encore! booklet]; (9) 08-25-1991, Pasadena Jazz Festival, Candid shots - mall; (10) 08-25-1991, Pasadena Jazz [Festival] Weekend, Dizzy Gillespie; (11) 08-07-1993 and 08-08-1993, Pasadena Jazz Festival, Candids - mall; (12) 08-08-1993 and 08-07-1994, Pasadena Jazz Festival, Candids - mall, Diane Schuur, Joe Henderson, Rickey Woodard; (13) 08-08-1993 and 08-07-1994, Pasadena Jazz Festival, Dave Grusin and Don Grusin, Earl Klugh; (14) American Indian Dance Company, Cecilia Bartoli, James Galway and Kazuhito Yamashita, Lionel Hampton, Emmylou Harris; (15) Shirley Jones, Juilliard Quartet, Yo-Yo Ma and Jeffrey Kahane, Paco Péña, Ivo Pogorelich; (16) Patrick Stewart, Mel Tormé, Vienna Choir Boys, Frederica von Stade; (17-18) [Miscellaneous photographic materials used in the production of Encore! booklet]; (19) [Miscellaneous printed matter used in the production of Encore! booklet, including programs, fliers, promotional/publicity materials, articles/clippings, and manuals/handbooks (Technical Package, describing audio/lighting/staging/video/projection/building layout for Ambassador, and Front of House Procedures, describing ushering/ticket procedures/emergency procedures/house policies/seating chart/general information)]; (20) [Empty folder designated as placeholder for two copies of the booklet "Encore! odd.head: General
odd.p: Recordings exist of many (but not all) of the concert performances at the Ambassador Auditorium. Some recordings were made in audio format and others in video format. The container lists provide information about the content of each tape. In some cases no program information was available, and during the processing of this collection, the audio recordings were not listened to, nor were the video recordings played back. Thus, even though all tapes have been listed, some listings do not include program information. Information about the recordings was taken from two sources: (1) date and reel identification number information as they appear on the tape boxes or on the reels themselves, and (2) artist and repertoire information from printed concert programs (see Series 4). If encores were performed and the information recorded by Ambassador personnel, then the encore title information is included in the Scope and Contents Note as well.

NB: The Doug Russell Collection (ARS.0054) at Stanford University's Archive of Recorded Sound contains 64 additional recordings of concerts presented at the Ambassador Auditorium between 1991 and 1995. For further information about those recordings, please consult the finding aid for the Doug Russell Collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Audio and video concert recordings in Series 10 had been organized separately by the Ambassador personnel into two distinct classifications of recordings. Those classifications have been maintained as two sub-series, and wherever practical, the original order of tapes has also been maintained.

did.unittitle: Audio Open Reel Tapes and Cassettes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Audio tapes were numbered by the Ambassador Auditorium in a sequence that generally follows chronological order. The original numerical order has been maintained and the Ambassador tape and reel numbers have been included in the title information for each box in the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tapes are identified by four-digit numbers assigned by the Ambassador organization, and the numbering system generally follows chronological order. In the listing below audio tapes are identified by the Ambassador tape number followed by the reel numbers, all enclosed in parentheses.

(7401:1-2) Ted Mack, 05-21-1974: [Ted Mack hosted an Amateur Talent Contest with students and faculty participants at the Ambassador Auditorium on this date. For more information, see Box 330, Folder 8.330.3]

(7501:1-2) Roger Wagner, 01-1975: [Roger Wagner conducted the Los Angeles Master Chorale and the Sinfonia Orchestra at the Ambassador Auditorium on 01-12-1975 and 01-13-1975. For more information, see Box 330, Folder 8.330.23]

(7503:1-2) Endre Balogh, violin; Bert Shefter, piano, 09-11-1975: Wieniawski, Henri, 1835-1880. Polonaise brillante, no. 1; arr. -- Bloch, Ernest, 1880-1959. Baal Shem. Nigun -- Bazzini, Antonio, 1818-1897. Ronde des lutins -- Chopin, Frédéric, 1810-1849. Impromptus, piano, no. 4, op. 66, C♯ minor -- Rachmaninoff, Sergei, 1873-1943. Preludes, piano, op. 23. No. 5 -- Ravel, Maurice, 1875-1937. Bolero, orchestra; arr.

(7504:2) Luciano Pavarotti, tenor; John Wustman, piano, 09-24-1975: Bononcini, Giovanni, 1670-1747. Griselda. Per la gloria d'adorarvi -- Tre giorni son che Nina -- Scarlatti, Alessandro, 1660-1725. odd.head: General
